review_needed: The 'Trombone' instrument's data is presented in a single table row where the 'Melodia' and 'Arranjo' cells contain multiple concatenated sections (e.g., 'Intro 1', '1A', '1B', '3 (resposta)') without internal newlines. The parsing assumes each bold section name within these cells denotes a new section, and the text following it (until the next section name or end of cell) is its single line of melody/arrangement. This deviates from the standard 'Melodia'/'Arranjo' table format where sections are typically defined by rows or external headings, and lines are separated by newlines. This also means sections like '1A' only have 'melody' and '1B' only have 'arrangement', which might not align with the intended full structure.

The 'Trompete' instrument's data is presented in a single table row where the 'Melodia' and 'Arranjo' cells contain multiple concatenated sections (e.g., 'Intro 1', '1A', '1B', '3 (resposta)') without internal newlines. The parsing assumes each bold section name within these cells denotes a new section, and the text following it (until the next section name or end of cell) is its single line of melody/arrangement. This deviates from the standard 'Melodia'/'Arranjo' table format where sections are typically defined by rows or external headings, and lines are separated by newlines. This also means sections like '1A' only have 'melody' and '1B' only have 'arrangement', which might not align with the intended full structure.
